text: A coast road. Date palms. Burnt-out hulks that once were  Russian T-54 TANKS have long ago been left to rust in the sun. A 4-door MERCEDES hurtles down the ancient road.
We're online for exactly two minutes.
Of the same scene. A grainy IMAGE of the car, and some  distance away, a moving cluster of animals. They are:
As seen at ground level. Two SHEPHERDS goad them forward. the distance, the MERCEDES approaches.
U.S. Army medics and rescue workers frantically sift thro the rubble of a collapsed barracks.
"...the single worst casualty in the  history of American military --"
The Mercedes barrels down the road, doing at least 80 mph
Shows that the car is fast approaching the point where th herd of sheep are about to cross the road.
Amidst the rubble, the dead are zipped into body bags.
"-- the truck, carrying high  explosives is believed to have hit  the barracks --
The driver of the Mercedes hits his horn but doesn't slow down. In addition to the driver and a bodyguard, an OLD M WITH A HENNAED BEARD, a turban, and sunglasses sits in ba
As the Mercedes closes with the sheep:
Slow down.
As if on command, the Mercedes finally slows as the sheep move lazily across the road.
President Clinton addresses reporters in the White House.
"To any lengths, anywhere in the  world, to bring these people to  justice."
Inside the Mercedes, they watch as the Shepherd urinates the sheep mill about in the middle of the road. The drive rolls down his window to scream in Arabic at:
Who hurries to button his fly. It is only as we look clos that we see the silenced muzzle of:
Protruding from the sleeve of his jhallabah. And then:
Fill the frame, blocking our view of the Mercedes, and fo moment, all we can HEAR is their gentle bleating. But as  they clear frame, we can see that:
Has been turned into an abattoir, its windshield shattere and bloody. The driver slumps over the steering wheel, th bodyguard is half out of the window. And in the distance:

One Shepherd pulls a BLACK HOOD over the Sheik's head whi the other injects him with a HYPODERMIC. The first Shephe activates a SATCHEL CHARGE and swings it into the Mercede while the second straps the Sheik into a HARNESS... A BAL self-inflates and hurtles aloft, pulling a cable attached the Sheik's harness.
Its "Whiskers" in the nose of the aircraft snag the cable without slowing and roars off, the Sheik dangling unconsc beneath -- just as the satchel charges EXPLODE the Merced
Records impassively for a moment, then breaks up into sta
Gotcha.

A pale, diminished Sheik sits at a steelcase table. A STE COT and a STEEL TOILET. Closed-circuit cameras in the cor Opposite him: the man, whose voice we have only heard: GE WILLIAM DEVEREAUX -- and though he wears a civilian suit, his bearing betrays his pedigree. His considerable charm habitual skepticism are as much a product of self-discipl as his close-order drill.
Nobody knows you're here. Not your  people. Not even my President. You'll  die here alone and be buried unknown --  barring some miracle.
The SHEIK speaks a few words in Arabic.

-- God? GOD? (looks at him) What you eat. Whether you eat. Sleep.  Pain. Absence of pain. I decide. I  make the day and the night. Even the  way you got here -- a hand that  reached down from the sky? (looks at him) God? I am your new God.
A MUEZZIN climbs a spiral staircase, enters a turret-like room, CLICKS ON a microphone and CHANTS the call to praye
Allahuh Akbar...
HUNDREDS OF BELIEVERS prostrate themselves on prayer rugs At the door, hundreds of SHOES are lined up, work boots,  expensive loafers, a range of social classes represented.
Shopkeepers pause to kneel and pray. In Arab homes, paren and children do the same. And as we PULL BACK from:
Of the Mosque, we DISCOVER not an Arab city, but instead unmistakable skyline of:
The World Trade Ctr, Wall Street, The Federal building.
Two AGENTS hurry through the bullpen. TINA OSU, 32, sharp and FRANK HADDAD, Lebanese with an insouciant grin.
Brooklyn South issued a code blue  less than two minutes ago. They think  hostages are involved.
Black-and-whites on the scene?
Setting up a perimeter now.
Residence or business?
A bus.
Sequence omitted from original script.
Surrounded by a phalanx of Black-and-Whites.
They have been joined by Anthony Hubbard, the ASAC.
SWAT?
On the way.
Negotiator?
Rolling.
Bomb squad?
The BOMB SQUAD approaches. We SEE terrified PASSENGERS in
How soon can we get there --?
In this traffic, maybe tomorrow.
As a police TECHIE inserts a dentist's mirror through a  drilled hole in the bus's door, the L.E.D. begins to BLIN and the passengers SCREAM and dive for cover. An EXPLOSIO
Frank is listening to a cell phone.
Oh, fuck. It just blew.
The doors hang off their hinges. As the PASSENGERS tumble off, we SEE they are covered in BLUE PAINT.
-- What?!
-- That's what they're telling me.
-- And nobody's hurt?
Frank nods. Hubs closes his eyes in gratitude.
Thank God.

head_text.subj: THE JOINT FBI/NYPD TERRORISM TASK FORCE

text: They're listening to a tape-recording, altered by a VO-CO
-- our first and last warning.
As the MESSAGE continues, we PAN the faces: MIKE JOHANNSO squad supervisor, and DANNY SUSSMAN, representing NYPD.
We expect our demand to be met. There  will be no negotiation. That is all.
Demand for what? You hear any demand?
You sure this is all they got?
That's it.
Maybe it's performance art.
Sussman shoots him a look. Clearly Haddad enjoys pushing buttons. Finally, Hub stands up.
-- Okay. Blue paint. Voice-altering  technology --
-- available from The Sharper Image  catalogue.
Last I looked they weren't offering  exploding paint bombs.
Still, the rhetoric sounds political.  Militia?
Not their style.
Frank --?
Jihad isn't known for their sense of  humor, and Hamas is raising so much  money here, why queer their deal?
Anyway, isn't Green the color of  Islam, not blue?
-- And, excuse me, but why do we  immediately assume they're Arabs?
I want a composite of the suspects  in circulation by the end of business  today. Tina, you cross-check it  against the mainframe. Mike, have  you got the lab analysis on the paint?
Not yet...
-- See if any was sold in quantity  the last month. Danny --
Tina's phone buzzes. She picks it up as Hub keeps going:
-- find out what stop these guys got  on the bus, maybe there's a witness.
Hub... I think we're all eager to  give up our weekends on this. It  just occurs to me, has anybody even  committed a crime here? I mean,  assault with a deadly color?
Hub deals with Haddad's irreverence by ignoring it.
Here's what I don't like. They know  explosives. They know our response  time. They put in a call and walk.
A young agent, FRED DARIUS, hands Hub a piece of paper:
Excuse me, sir. I think you should  see this. Came in on the Fax.
Only two words are written: "RELEASE HIM."
Release him? Him who? Who are we  holding?
Marv Albert?
McVeigh? Sheik what's-his-name from  the Trade Center.
-- Omar Abdel Rahman... asshole.
The Hamas guy got released in April.
Under protest.
(looks at the fax) Why be coy about it?
You think it's phony?

(covering the phone) Hub, somebody's flashing a government  badge over at the warehouse where  they're working on the bus. Our tech  guys want to know if we're cooperating  with any other agencies on this thing.
Off Hub's look, we:
Hub and Haddad join AGENT FLOYD ROSE, a tall Black man.
-- She's looking for wiring signatures  on the device and asking for copies  of any latent prints we've managed  to lift.
-- Agency?
Smells like it. Turns out she's also  been talking to some of the  passengers.

In the klieg lights -- THE BUS. Men in white coats dust e inch and generally behave as if investigating a crashed U In their midst, a young WOMAN, midwestern pretty in a ser suit. She looks up as Hub enters.
Hi.
Hi, there.
Special Agent Anthony Hubbard. FBI.
Oh, shit, I've been trying to liaise  with you all day. My name is Elise  Kraft, National Security Council.
She offers her hand. Hub doesn't take it yet.
-- And you've been trying to "liaise"  with me all day? Did you think of  trying the phone book, Elise? We  have fourteen lines, that's not  counting the unlisted ones.
(still holds out hand) Hi, I'm Elise Kraft, National Security  Council.
Finally, he takes her hand. And doesn't let go.
And I'm Colin Powell. What exactly  do you people want with my bus.
She tries to take her hand away, but he tightens his grip
We're all on the same team here,  Agent Hubbard.
Who exactly is "we" on this particular  team, Elise?
It's never the question that's  indiscreet, only the answer.
He smiles. She smiles back. Convinced she's charmed him.

Tell you what, you send me an official  inter-agency request for cooperation  on this and I'll give you copies of  everything we come up with. Otherwise,  get your ass on out of here before  you contaminate my crime scene any  more than you already have.
There's no reason to be nasty.
You think this is nasty? (smiles) In case you haven't heard. The CIA  has no charter to operate  domestically. Which puts you in  violation of federal law.
Not according to the Cooperation  Agreement, Special Order 12333 -- I  suggest you reread the paragraph on  sharing information. I happen to be  well within my authority.
Special Order 12333 refers to domestic  terrorism. You got something you  want to "share" with me? (he waits... but no  answer is forthcoming) Us being teammates and all?
(holds up a clipboard) Unfortunately, not yet. But as soon  as I do, I'll --

-- get back to me, yeah, I know. (takes the clipboard  from her hands) Here's what I'm gonna do. I'm gonna  have a couple my "teammates" here  escort you back to wherever you came  from. And then I'm gonna go back to  the office and wait for that official  cooperation request. Okay by you?
Swell.
Nice meeting you, Elise. Is that  Elise with an "E" or an "A"?
Nice meeting you, too, Special Agent  Hubbard.
Hub watches as Elise is led away by two AGENTS. Agent Ros stands nearby.
Tail her.
In Frank Haddad's home. The Haddad's are celebrating the FRANK JR. has finished reading the Holy Koran.
(in Arabic) "In the Name of Allah, the beneficent,  the merciful. Say: I seek refuge in  the Lord of Men, the King of Men."
Frank's TEACHER offers the final benediction. Those who a Muslim cover their face with their palms.

(in Arabic) "Make me know that which I have become  ignorant of; and make me recite it  in the hours of the night and the  day; and make it an argument for me  O Thou Sustainer of all the worlds!"  Ameen!
Ameen.
Later -- The guests mingle, eat pastries and drink sweet tea.
...Nice, wasn't it?
Very.
(after a moment) You ever gonna stop by, pick up your  things?
Nearby, Mike and Danny observe them.
-- He doing her?
Some detective you are. They stopped.
Really? I wonder if she likes white  guys.
I wonder if she likes bald guys.
Hub, meanwhile, congratulates Frank's wife, NAJIBA.
You must be so proud...
Small children, small worries. Big  children --
-- big orthodontia bills. Someday,  you'll understand.
And then Frank notices Hub's DRIVER standing in the doorw
Where we going?
You're staying with your family. I'm  back in the morning.
Sequence omitted from original script. Sequence omitted from original script. (ALREADY SHOT)
Hub is looking at surveillance photos of Elise. Frank ent
You sleep here? (Hub smiles, but  doesn't look up) Immigration called.
Hub and Frank watch a dark-skinned MAN being questioned b uniformed OFFICIAL. An INS Supervisor shows them a false- bottomed suitcase stuffed with money.
-- all in small bills. So we figure,  smurf, right? Then I think,  considering the gentleman's  nationality, plus where he's been  recently, we better call Frank.
-- who's trying to score points with  his boss, bigtime.
Has he broken any laws?
No, sir. He's twenty bucks under the  $10,000 limit.
(pulls out a $20 bill) Not anymore.
The official hopes volume breaks the language barrier.
...so, Kahlil, you're saying this is  an INHERITANCE? Somebody DIED and  you're bringing them the MONEY?
The dark-skinned man is trying to keep up:
No, no... dhouri.
...He means, "dowry."
Check out his neck.
Small puckered SCARS. The INS guy looks confused.
The tabac. (mimics putting out a  cigarette on his arm) Sssssss... The territories.
(thinks a moment) Put him in play.
Hub and Frank in a rental CONTOUR, tail Khalil, in a cab:
(on the phone) -- on the Van Wyck... No, not yet. (to Frank) -- What are we in?
A '97 Contour. On my Visa. (watches Khalil) Back home, the security services'd  be up this guy's ass with a poker,  but what do we do, we let him go.
(still on the phone) ...Six teams on the ground, at  least... well, pull 'em off the UN... (to Haddad) Stay back...
Not my first date, Hub. (the TAXI changes  lanes) He's taking the BQE. Looks like it's  Brooklyn.
(still on the phone) I want husbands and wives, I want  baby carriages, and no Brooks  Brothers.
You're micro-managing.
(still on the phone) -- And find me a judge I can work  with. We want sound on this guy...  damn'... I'm losing you... (raises his voice) And bring us a radio.
I get reimbursed for this, right?

The Third World. Teeming, roiling, Kinshasha meets Beirut meets Tel Aviv meets Moscow. Hand-written shop signs in A and Hebrew, boom boxes throbbing out "Oum Khatoum," the l neo-Palestinian techno-rock. KHALIL pays the taxi driver and starts off on foot. Hub's CONTOUR pulls over a safe distance behind and waits. An A passes by and slips a WALKIE-TALKIE through the open wind
Falls in behind Khalil, who ducks into a storefront, wher WE CAN SEE him buying a Coca Cola and a Baby Ruth bar.
(notes the purchase) Twelve bucks in Gaza.
America's the place to be if you're  a terrorist. (on the walkie-talkie) Fred's hovering. Patsy, take over...
A WOMAN WITH A STROLLER replaces the man carrying groceri
...Tell her to watch out for  reflections.
(hands him the phone) I got the Judge.
(on the phone) ...Good morning, Sir. How're things  in the Second Circuit this morning...?  ...I hear you... Listen, Judge, we're  in a kind of situation here...
KHALIL is on the move again.
(on the phone) Hold on, will ya, Judge? (into walkie-talkie) Is he talking to somebody, who's he  talking to? Are we getting film?
An AGENT with a TELEPHOTO snaps a picture of Khalil, who paused to chat with a PALESTINIAN of patrician good-looks
(covering the phone) -- Frank?
Don't know him. If we were allowed  to get sound on them, we'd know him.
The walkie-talkie CRACKLES TO LIFE, confirming the photos

(covering the radio) ...What's that? No, Judge, not yet  we're not... but we have reason to  believe he may be involved with -- (covers the phone  again; keys the radio) Damnit Tommy! (to Frank) He's overacting! Tell him -- (back to the phone) Sorry, Judge... No... I just --
He's making him. Shit. Fuck. He's --
Khalil has a sixth sense from a lifetime on the West Bank All of a sudden, he BREAKS INTO A RUN.
(keys radio) Go, go, go!!! All units --
He slams the car into gear and PEELS OUT into traffic.

In various guises, break cover and SPRINT after Khalil, w shifts into overdrive. Cars SCREECH to avoid flattening h Hub's CONTOUR pulls into traffic and finds his way blocke by a narrow passage between double-parked cars. He goes f it, SCRAPING his way between them.
Christ!
(on the phone) Judge, I'm gonna have to call you  back...

Into an open-air MARKET, KNOCKING DOWN veiled WOMEN with  bags of fruit and vegetables. He VAULTS over stalls. The CONTOUR scrapes PARKED CARS as it swerves into an all desperately trying to cut off Khalil's escape route.
Shit --! I didn't take the insurance.
A SOCCER BALL bounces into Hub's peripheral vision, follo by TWO BOYS.

head_text.subj: HUB SLAMS THE CONTOUR INTO THE WALL

text: To avoid killing the two boys. Hub gets out of the car an continues the pursuit on foot. He's gaining on Khalil, wh
Bears down on Khalil, its doors sliding open as TWO PAIRS HANDS reach out and ANOTHER MAN appears out of nowhere an BODYCHECKS Khalil into the van and jumps in after him.
What the --?
The van BURNS RUBBER and DISAPPEARS into traffic.
An impromptu huddle in the alley. AGENTS gather in a circ as RADIOS SQUELCH and HELICOPTERS circle above.
They just found the van. Doesn't  look like they're gonna find any  prints.
The Agent who took the pictures pulls a color xerox-type  PHOTO from a digital printer in his car. Hub looks at the picture of Khalil and the good-looking Palestinian.
Run him down, bring him in.
Fred hands a cell phone to Hub.
Floyd Rose.
Go, Floyd.
As he listens, the first trace of a smile graces Hub's fa
In an ordinary neighborhood. Hub sits in an UNMARKED CAR. Agent Rose climbs into the front seat.
I've got two in the Plymouth, at  least three inside, and see that guy  walking his dog...? He did his  business about an hour ago and they're  still walking.
I had a dog like that once.
It's not his dog, numbnuts. They're  spies.
The dog works for the CIA?
Their radio CRACKLES to life. It's Hub.
(over the radio) All units report in turn.
We HEAR "Unit 1 is good to go," "Unit 2, we're ready to r
Let's roll.
Is suddenly double-teamed by TWO AGENTS.
Federal Agents. Hands behind your  back --
A third AGENT throws his jacket over the dog.
Fishtail across the quiet street, boxing in the Plymouth an AGENT from the sidewalk thrusts a 12-gauge Remington P in through the driver's window.
-- Keep 'em where we can see 'em,  thank you very much.
Is BLOWN-IN by a specially-designed SHOTGUN. Two MEN, eat take-out are surprised by Frank and Tina, their guns draw
Hi, guys, I expect you know the drill.
Hub continues warily from one empty room to the next. A  stairway leads downstairs. As Hub starts cautiously down, muted VOICES can be heard. Reaching the bottom, he sees:

Sitting in a chair. Behind him stands one of FREELANCERS  from the warehouse. And opposite him, in a barca-lounger: ELISE KRAFT -- Somehow amidst the normalcy of the furnish basement is a palpable feeling of menace. As Hub shows himself, one of the Freelancers points a Glo .9 at his head. Hub just stares him down.
Ralph, spare us.
The freelancer lowers the gun. Hub looks at Khalil, whose face is badly bruised.
I never touched him.
Really? I'm taking him into custody  just the same.
What are you going to charge him  with? Jaywalking? (Hub stares at her) I don't suppose we could just have a  little chat with him here first?
Not in this lifetime.

You know, Hub... may I call you Hub?  If you guys hadn't blown the  surveillance, we'd have been able to  follow the money. What do you think,  Khalil, you would have led us right  to your friends, wouldn't you?
Khalil averts his eyes from any contact with her.
What friends --? What have you got  for me, Elise?... Enlighten me. (she stonewalls) Tell me now or tell me downtown.
Still nothing. Hub calls out to his agents.
Get this guy out of here and book  him.
As the other agents approach Khalil:
One phone call and he's mine again.  You know the number. I have --
You have "the right to remain silent,"  you have "the right to an attorney.  Anything you say can and will be  held against you in a court of law -- "
(overlapping him) Oh, come on... Do you have any idea  what you're starting here, the kind  of shitstorm you're about to --
(overiding her) -- Kidnapping. Obstruction of Justice.  Assault.
As he heads out of the room, he says to a waiting Agent.
Cuff her.
Elise sits, handcuffed, alone in the back seat. Up front, Frank is driving with Hub beside him.
So, Elise... You okay back there,  you don't get carsick or anything?  Those handcuffs too tight --?
Shouf mountains, right? Shiite or  Sunni?
Wow. You're really good. (to Hub) She's really good.
You ready to tell us what's going on  here, Elise --? Was the paintbomb a  warning?
(to Haddad) American University of Beirut? I was  there from '79 to 82.
(a look to Hub) No shit?
My father taught Economics. Henry  Kraft?
Is there a terrorist cell operating  in this city that we are unaware of?
(ignoring him; to  Haddad) Such a tragedy. Growing up in that  city was... paradise. Like an exotic  Paris, wasn't it, Frank --?
You ever been in Rikers, Elise? You  know what happens in there?
Elise looks at him, utterly unfazed by the threat.
...Yum.
Frank's BEEPER goes off. As they look at one another, we:

Red lights flashing, have sealed off a Brooklyn Street. O the rooftops SWAT teams are already deploying. SHARPSHOOTERS politely insinuate themselves into the  surrounding family APARTMENTS and take up firing POSITION

Stands alone in the middle of the street. Through a Marks SCOPE we SEE the terrified passengers forced to stand, ca glimpses of the TERRORISTS, obscured by the hostages. Hub confers with the NYPD officer-in-charge.
-- definitely Arab-types, only this  time they're still in there...
Any communication at all?
Nope. It's weird they're just in  there.
Get the frequency of the driver's  radio and patch it through to this  number. We need two lines. Frank,  get a negotiator out here.
Sir, they've got kids in there. We  count six.
This rocks Hub for a moment but he covers it well.
That gives us something to work with.
Elise leans forward as Hub opens the driver's door.
What's happening out there...
Hub takes off his jacket, folds it carefully on the seat.
They've taken another bus, haven't  they? Talk to me...
Oh, now you want to talk. You want  to be my friend, is that it?
Listen, these guys are the real deal.
How do you know?
She just looks at him.
Is there a terrorist cell operating  in Brooklyn?
(a long moment) Yes.
Was the blue paint a warning?
Yes. And I'm afraid this time they'll  blow the bus.
If they wanted to blow the bus then  why haven't they blown the bus --?
I... don't know.
He starts away.
Agent Hubbard. Please. Maybe I can  help.
Has been hastily improvised behind a SWAT van.
The driver's name is Larry Kaiser.  He says they've got explosives  strapped to their chests, they got  automatic weapons, and they're  speaking Arabic.
Where the hell's the negotiator?
Tunnel's got twenty minute delays  and they're working on both bridges.
(to the cop) What else did he say about the device?  Did he describe it at all? Anything  about a button, or a cord, or...
Pulls up and raises its satellite dish.
(almost involuntary) Oh, God.
Frank turns to look at her. She is suddenly pale.
(as it dawns on her) ...They're not here to negotiate.
Meaning?
They were waiting for the cameras.
Hub is deep in conversation with the cops. Frank interrup
Hub looks up. Frank nods for Elise to repeat what she sai
They're want the newsies here. They  want everybody watching.
Hub and Frank look at each other. Can this be true?
You've got the shooters in place?
-- So?
Use 'em.
What?
Kill 'em now.
They just look at her.
It's lose-lose any way you play it...  Do you want to lose little or lose  big?
The NYPD officer has been listening:
I got the marksmen on the com --  They're looking for a clean shot.

As the Policeman waits for a response on his radio, two m NEWS VANS pull up. The MEDIA CIRCUS has come to town:  reporters breathlessly offer their live, on-the-scene rep Hub and Elise stare at one another.
Shooter says they've got the  passengers all standing in the aisles.  He says, no go.
Hub can see the dread in Elise's eyes. As the seconds tic away, TWO NEWS HELICOPTER jockey for position above.
(to the cops) We have rules of engagement we're  gonna follow here, folks, so put the  safeties back on your weapons. (looks at Elise) Nobody's killing anybody until we  see what's what.
He grabs the phone.

(on the phone) Larry, this is Agent Hubbard of the  FBI, I'll be negotiating our way out  of this. Let me talk to one of them...  I know... I know. You just hang in  there, Larry... No, don't worry,  I've got somebody here who can  translate.
He looks over at Frank, who's listening on another cell.

(on the phone) Sir, -- My name is Anthony Hubbard.  I don't have any authority to make  deals, or respond to demands. I just  want to find out if you need anything  in there? If any of the passengers  are in need of medical attention?
He waits as Frank translates. Hub covers the mouthpiece.
-- Frank?
I don't know if they understand.
(on the phone) Sir, is there anything you want to  say to me? That I can tell my people  here?
The guy's just breathing into the  phone, maybe they're not even Arabs.
(on the phone) I get the feeling you don't want to  talk, but will you listen --?  ...Whatever grievance you have,  whatever quarrel -- surely it doesn't  involve these children --
Still no response.
(on the phone) So I'm gonna ask you to... please...  let... the... children go.

No response -- then suddenly, the bus doors HISS OPEN And six bewildered, ashen-faced CHILDREN step out before doors HISS closed behind them. As Hub and a couple of the cops hurry out from behind the barricades to help the chi cross the NO-MAN'S LAND to safety, a smattering of APPLAU breaks out among the cops. Elise tries to hold back tears
Okay, here we go...

(on the phone) Thank you, sir. I appreciate that  gesture, I really do. The best way  to get what you want in these  situations is to show yourself to be  reasonable. As you've just done. (Haddad translates) Now we've got some more to talk  about...
Elise watches as the news cameras zoom in.

(on the phone) I am unarmed, as you can see. So I  propose... You let the rest of the  passengers go, and I take their  place... That way, there's no pizza  deliveries or bathroom breaks to  worry about -- and all these -- (indicates SWAT teams) -- people... will disappear.
Frank shakes his head, don't do this. Hub's look says  translate it. Frank does it. They all wait.
(on the phone) I'm gonna take your silence to mean  you're considering my offer --
Elise looks at Frank, she can't help but admire his brave
How about we just start with a few  of the elderly people you got on  there. It's got to be hard for the  older folks to be standing all this  time.
Hub looks back at Frank. Still no response. AND THEN THE BUS DOORS HISS OPEN AGAIN. A few elderly  PASSENGERS start down the steps.
(on the phone) Thank you, sir. Now let's just let  these --
Hurls Hub backwards as:
To be replaced by a high-end, almost electronic WHITE NOI
Imbeds itself into car doors, bus benches, doorways as ev WINDOW in a three-block radius is SHATTERED...
Replaces blue paint in a horrific shower.
Fights for consciousness.

Rush to his side to see if he is alright -- but WE CANNOT HEAR them. Though their mouths move it is only the WHITE  NOISE that overwhelms us -- as we realize that Hub has be momentarily DEAFENED by the blast. When at last Hub manages to speak, his words are MUFFLED INDISTINCT -- as if the playback heads of a tape recorder needed to be cleaned.
I'm... alright. I'm --
Frank Haddad bends down close and we can lip-read him say "Just hang in there, buddy. . ."
-- okay... Just let me --
And then he leans over to VOMIT in the street.

Slowly bleeds in through the white noise -- mercifully fo us, and for Hub, who wipes his mouth and looks up, realiz that his HEARING is coming back. He reaches for Frank's  outstretched hand and stands, albeit woozily.
Is anybody --
But the look in Frank's eyes says it all.
Is numbing. IMAGES we associate with other countries. And then he sees Elise. Her face is cut and bleeding, but as  their eyes meet, her look is one of absolute compassion.
Crowded into the now-overflowing BULLPEN. In absolute den of his physical condition, Hub paces like a caged animal.

-- every trap, every hole. I want to  rumble every mosque, every community  center, every student organization  that's ever said an unkind word. I  want the heat turned up under all  our assets, all our informers, every  snitch gets twisted inside out. And  put some money out on the street --  Arab community hates these people as  much as we do. They'll help. (turns to Mike) Have you got positive ID on --
Hub, we don't have positive ID on  anybody.
We need more hands. Fred --
I'm on it.
He picks up a phone and begins requesting Agent transfers
I want to talk to Khalil.
He's down the hall.
Now she picks up a phone and adds to the cacophony.

-- Conferences with DC at 9:00, 12:00,  4:00 and 9:00. Call your families,  find a sleeping bag, nobody leaves  this office until we have a strand  to pull. Oklahoma City, people. The  first twenty-four hours are the only  twenty-four hours.. And I don't want  to see anybody walking.
Hub and Frank watch Khalil through a VIDEO MONITOR. The  bruises on Khalil's face have deepened.
Doctor seen him?
He's on his way up.
Got a cigarette --?
You don't smoke.
Hub pockets the pack of cigarettes and walks into:
Frank hangs back in the doorway. Hub pulls up a chair, tu it backwards, and sits down very close to Khalil.
Ten thousand dollars.
Frank translates. Khalil pretends not to understand.
Khalil. I want to talk about the  money.
Again Frank translates. And again, Khalil looks blank.
Okay...

Hub reaches into his pocket and casually takes out the pa of cigarettes. Khalil's eyes widen. Hub smiles at him. At the SOUND of the match lighting, SWEAT begins to bead on  Khalil's forehead. Hub takes his time LIGHTING the cigare drawing deep so the tip turns bright red. Khalil unconsci RECOILS in his chair.
(to Frank, re: Khalil) Doesn't like second hand smoke.
Hub turns back to Khalil, casually gesturing with his  cigarette. Khalil almost jumps out of his skin.
You ready to talk about money?
Frank hasn't even begun to translate before Khalil begins SPEED-RAPPING in Arabic.
(translating) ...He says he loves America and only  wanted to get away from the security  services at home.
Tears stream down Khalil's face. He kneels at Hub's feet.

(still translating) ...He says he's sorry but he didn't  know he was doing something bad. His  cousin introduced him to a man who  promised him two hundred dollars for  his dowry if he'd bring the suitcase  to an address in Brooklyn. (to Hub) He's a cut-out.
Hub hands Tina back the pack of cigarettes.
Nasty habit. (to Danny) 3830 Flatbush Avenue.
Bursts into an empty apartment. On the floor, a fax machi continuously sending the message: "RELEASE HIM."
We want every rental agreement from  every landlord in Brooklyn. Hotels,  motels, flophouses... (to the other agents) It's cash, guys. They're the only  ones in America using cash.
The room is dark. A TECHNICIAN operates an overhead PROJE

This is a spectograph of the semtex  used in the bomb. Look at the benzene  spike. This is the genuine article. (another slide) Now... this one's from the barracks  in Dhahran. As you can see, the  signature is identical.
A COMPUTER TECHIE (WHITNEY) is cross-referencing data. DI PICTURES of suspected terrorists scroll past. A surveilla PHOTO of Ahmed bin Talal. The ruined army barracks.
-- ask it if they've ever hit buses?
The techie types in a few commands: IMAGES of destroyed B file past. Tel Aviv. Jerusalem. Beirut. None a match.
-- not according to the mainframe.

The BOMB SCENE now resembles an archeological dig. Floodl on stanchions. Forensic EXPERTS, on their hands and knees use BLACK LIGHT and brushes to search for latent prints.  Different color STRING divides the site into a grid.
-- with a Q-tip. Bone shards, hair,  fingernails --
Nearby, Danny and Mike observe Hub's intensity.
-- He's way over his head.
Shut the fuck up and go give somebody  a parking ticket.
In THE LAB. A FINGERPRINT EXPERT sifts through a plastic of fingertips and teeth. Scans each into a computer.
Not yet.
Sequence omitted from original script.
Hub is STARING AT THE TV SETS which are all REPLAYING the terrible incident, over and over again.
"-- Today; Tel Aviv has come to  Brooklyn. The question... is why."
Finally, he turns away so no one will see. His eyes are h with the emotion.
You okay?
The Fingerprint techie races in, sparing Hub a response.
Got one!
Hub and Tina address twenty agents.
Ladies and Gentlemen, meet the late  Ali Waziri.
He projects a PHOTO of the dead Terrorist onto the wall.
Tina talked to the Israelis and traced  this sucker to a group operating out  of Ramallah. That's the West Bank,  not the West Side for those of you  just joining us from Nebraska.
A few appreciative CHUCKLES. They're all exhausted. This the first good news in a bitch of a day.
Okay, we've pulled his landing card  and his I-94. So now we know he came  in three days ago, out of Frankfurt --
She points to where: A TIME-LINE has been created out of  colored strips beneath a bank of silent TV monitors.
What we need now is to fill in the  time between his arrival and the  incident. All known associations,  and most of all, we need an address.
The TIME-LINE is progressing. PHONE TECHNICIANS add tie-l dedicated fax lines, wats lines and scrambled lines. Cabl everywhere. Danny and Frank pore over Ali Waziri's I-94.
IAP66. What's IAP66?
Hold on, hold on, I'm looking it up --
-- Today, Danny...
Wait, wait -- Here we go. Student  Visa, J-1.
Hub has been pacing, nearby.
Where's the original --?
In his passport.
Which is... vaporized.
Where's the copy?
At the point of issuance. Could be  the American Consulate in Tel Aviv.  The American Consulate in Amman,  Cairo, Alexandria, Riyadh -- all an  easy drive from the West Bank --
Hub suddenly had to fight off a wave of nausea and dizzin
What time is it --?
Three-fifteen. P.M. (off Hub's blank look) When's the last time you ate?
Fred Darius, the young agent, appears.
Sir. They want you in the lab.
Hub peers through the eyepiece at a MAGNIFIED STRAND of f
Pure, unadulterated, Egyptian cotton.
You're saying they're Egyptian?
No. No... I'm just saying -- See...
-- It's what they use for funerals.  The guy was wearing a shroud.
He looks at Frank. It's just as Elise said. The real deal
Let's see if she's ready to talk.
Elise sits quietly with the stillness of those who have b there before. Hub enters.
I thought one phone call and you  were out of here.
I didn't make the call.
Why not?
She just looks at him, entirely neutral.
Are you alright --?
Just some tinnitus in my left ear --
They look across the professional chasm that divides them
I need to know what I don't know.
Life's too short.
But there's a hint of some thawing in her tone.
You hungry?
We ordering in --?
Sequence omitted from original script.
Hub and Elise sit, eating corned beef sandwiches.
-- The funeral shroud is the final  step in the ritual of self- purification. First a fast, then --
-- the washing of the body, then the  shroud. I saw it on Sixty Minutes.  Tell me something I don't know.
She pauses, always gauging how much to reveal. And when.
...Last March in Iraq, we identified  the man we believe responsible for  bombing the army barracks last year.  In August, he went to Lebanon. Where  he was... extracted.
Extracted? Extracted by whom? (she just looks at  him) I see.
His name is Sheik Ahmed bin Talal.  He's Iraqi. And something of a  religious leader.
With something of a devoted following? (she nods) ...Okay, I can understand why we  might not want to publicize the fact  that our government's in the  kidnapping business, but why not  tell us?
He's still being... debriefed. They're  not ready to go public with charges.
What else you got on his followers.
Clearly, they're committed.
Meaning?
In this game, the most committed  wins.
So they'll just keep coming until we  release him.
Unless we match their commitment  with our own.
What about talking to this sheik?
You don't think they've got guys  talking to the sheik? Except the  sheik isn't talking.
So who's giving the orders? How do  they coordinate, pick their targets?
Believe me, we've put every resource  we've got onto that very question. (puts down her fork) Otherwise... we wait.
We wait.
She looks at him. For one brief moment the mask drops awa
If there's anybody on earth who knows  how you feel, it's me. But you've  got to let it go. Those people were  dead the minute they got on the bus.
Frank Haddad appears, making his way toward their table.
Sorry, boss. Hello, Elise. Mmmm, is  that pastrami? (tastes it; then with  his mouth full) Oh, yeah, we made the guy in the  picture.
Sequence omitted from original script.
Where Students sit inside and SMOKE, then SMOKE some more
My people. The last of the  unambivalent smokers. (shakes his head) Monsters. The toughest motherfucker  in Bed-Stuy is a muffin compared to  some of these guys.
They watch as SAMIR gets his bill from the waiter.
His name's Samir Nazhde. Teaches  Arab Studies at Brooklyn College. He  sponsored Ail Waziri's student visa.  And dig this -- his brother blew up  a movie theatre in Tel Aviv.
You might consider leaving him alone.
Why would I consider doing that --?
In the cafe, Samir counts cash to leave on the table.
Play him like a cop and haul him in  now and get your arrest, or tag him  and let him lead you to the really  big fish.
(an arabic curse) You're fishing and he's getting visas  for bombers.
You ever heard of catch and release?
Yes, and he's on the next plane for  Tunis.
Hub looks at Elise. Samir is leaving -- it's now or never
Take him down.
(keys his radio) Go.

THREE AGENTS brace Samir politely but firmly, and lead hi to their car. Samir slides into the back seat next to Eli In the REARVIEW MIRROR, Hub watches as a look seems to pa between them. Then again, it may not have happened.
Samir Nazhde, my name is Frank Haddad,  I'm a Federal Agent. We have reason  to believe you are an accessory to  the bombing of Bus 87.
Are you crazy --?
You are an associate of Ali Waziri.
Who? I know no one by that name.
Elise is looking out the window, seemingly oblivious.
You got him a student visa.
I sign these applications as a matter  of course, hundreds of them. Everyone  wants to come to the land of  opportunity and Baywatch.
Elise tries to keep a smile off her face. Hub clocks this
You spent two years in Israeli jails  during the Intifada.
The only ones who didn't were women  like you.
Frank BACKHANDS him across the mouth. Samir says somethin in Arabic to Frank, who responds in kind.
Frank --
Sorry. Family matter. (to Samir) You're going downtown, my friend.
You cannot hold me. I know my rights.  I watch American television.
Defrauding the INS is a Federal  Offense. (hands Samir to waiting  agents) Reservation for one, please.
They enter the BULLPEN. It's well past midnight. People a sacked-out in sleeping bags while others continue working
Club Fed.
Frank leans over Danny Sussman, who has fallen asleep, fa down on his desk, and sings in a lovely brogue:
(singing) "Oh, Danny-boy, the perps, the perps,  are call-ing... (as he awakens) We need a search warrant on Samir...
Frank, c'mere a sec. I want to show  you something.
He leads Frank into another CUBICLE. Perched on nearby de Elise is dialing a phone, she stops to watch them:
(quietly) Frank, you ever hit a prisoner again  I'll have your badge.
-- Someday I will tell you what those  people did to my village in '71.
Hub waits for him to calm down.
(touches his arm) Okay. But right now, act as if I'm  capable of saying something funny...  Now, let's go see about that warrant.
As they walk back, Hub says to Danny:
Find me a Judge who'll play ball  this time. And set up a polygraph  for Samir.
I still don't understand why we're  tipping our hand with him --
What's there to tip?
You're just trying to protect your  asset. (to Elise, pointedly:) Aren't you, Elise --? He's your Joe,  your asset. He's working for you,  you're his case officer -- right?
How should she respond? How thin should she slice it?
...Sometimes... in addition to being  a nationality, being a Palestinian  is also a... profession. A lucrative  one.
Meaning, he's your Joe.
Mine. Yours. The Israelis. The Saudis.  At one time or another, everybody in  the Middle East has slept with  everybody else.
So you're saying... you sleep around?
Only professionally.
So we share him.
No.
(to Frank) -- Call INS, find out his status and  start deportation proceedings.
I can't let you do that.
Oh, you can't let me do that. What  precisely is your involvement with  these people.
(sighs, then:) Samir's been a very important...  project of mine for some time... I'm  the only one he'll deal with. He's  very well-connected -- and extremely  high-strung.
...Call the judge.
(looks at Frank) How easy is it to get inside, Frank?  How good are your sources in the  mosques? How many people you got in  Hamas --?
Franks shakes his head, ruefully. She's right.
No surveillance. I've seen your deft  touch.
Daily reports. We tap his phone.
And I get to see the transcripts.
Fair enough.
And I run him.
We share him.
He can't know we're talking.
Then don't tell him.
Done.
(to Frank) Let him fly. (back to her) But we better start seeing product.
She nods. A deal. For now.
Any more surprises for me?
Not tonight.
Then I'm going home to get some  things.
I'll have somebody drive you.
I'll grab a cab.
And he's gone. Frank turns to Elise:
Elise. I'm really high strung, too.
She just smiles and walks away.
Not many people around. Hub stands on the corner. A TAXI  cruises up. On duty. Available. He slows long enough to s that Hub is black and passes right by.
The taxi driver stops just long enough for Hub to slam hi SHIELD on the windshield.
Hub sits in back, hurtling into the night. The driver's I identifies him as ABDUL HASSAM. Hub shakes his head.

As the hot SPRAY hits him, he runs his hands through his  hair and feels the BITS OF SHATTERED GLASS. Dried blood r off in rivulets from his hands. Not his own. He leans aga the shower wall, closes his eyes.
We are in her apartment. Samir looms over her.
You let him HIT ME --!! You cannot  care about me and let such things  happen!
Next time don't be such a smart ass --
Sometimes I hate you just because  you are so American. It makes me  want to hurt you. I think about  fucking you and hurting you.
Elise can taste the blood in her mouth -- but it's the pr she's come to accept. In a heartbeat, it's all business.
-- You want to fuck me? Then work  with me.
Don't tell me what I have to do.
No? Do we really want to have this  conversation again? Do we --?
Something quietly ominous in her tone. He lowers his eyes And like a sailboat, Elise changes tack. Strokes his arm.
I need you to help me. I need you to  be strong. As you have always been  strong. For both of us. -- Samir?  Look at me...
He's fallen asleep in a chair. In his lap is a pile of vi applications. His BEEPER goes off. He rouses himself.
Sex without any shred of tenderness. As Samir kisses the  back of her neck, we SEE in her eyes the thousand-yard st
In the doorway of an apartment building, Frank hands Hub styrofoam cup of coffee. It's a ritual between them.
-- Some people just cannot live in  the camps. For my brother, it was  already like dying. The only thing  he lives for is movies.
He sits up in bed, reaching for another cigarette.

-- And then some sheik tells him  that, to die for Allah is beautiful.  If he does this thing, our parents  will be taken care of, and he will  live on in Paradise with seventy  virgins. Seventy. (sighs) And my brother, he needs to believe  it very much, so he straps ten sticks  of dynamite to his chest and goes to  the movies... (a rueful laugh) And I become a VIP. It is very  confusing.
-- So who are you afraid of betraying?  You know these people. They bomb,  they maim. Do they represent the  Palestine you want to build? (looks at him) They're using you.
You are using me, too! Everybody  uses the Palestinians! We are the  whores of the Middle East! (looks at her) You make reports about our little  talks --? What about fucking me?
I had to get special permission for  that.
As he stands up, naked, and goes to the window, we SEE:
Seen again, FROM MUCH FARTHER AWAY by Hub who stands on a ROOFTOP across the way, watching through 1050 BINOCULARS. Frank stands beside him.
Beats cable.
Sequence omitted from original script. Sequence omitted from original script. Sequence omitted from original script. Sequence omitted from original script.
Hub heads for his office, his SECRETARY nods inside. Some is waiting. It's Devereaux, in a civilian suit.
Hi. I understand they call you Hub.
I know who you are, General.
(offering his hand) Bill Devereaux.
I served in the --
82nd Airborne, I know. Same time I  was running the --
-- 173rd. Put me through school.
God. Duty. Honor. Country. Where on  Capitol Hill, Wall Street, or  Hollywood would you find one man  who's even paused over one of those  words in the last ten years?
Hub is unsure why he's audience to such a command perform
What, uh, brings you here, General?...  Can I get you some coffee?
You want me to get to the point. The  President's concerned. He's worried  that -- have you met him by any  chance?
No, sir, I haven't. I know -- reading  the papers -- terrorism's a real  concern for him. And your job is to --

-- With all the affection for the  man I can tell you he doesn't know  fuckall about terrorism, or the  Mideast, that I don't put on his cue  cards. What he's expert in is his  own survival. You get my meaning?
I didn't guess you came all this way  for a cup of coffee.
Agent Hubbard -- you look like you  think I'm here to take your baby  away!
With all respect for your expertise,  sir. We're on track here.
Which is what I said to the President --  the Army is not some big green police  department. Stick with the man on  the ground.
I appreciate your support.
You're sure you're not chasing your  own tail, though?
Hub considers for a moment, then:
What do you know about Sheik Ahmed  Bin Talal?
Old news.
Maybe not. We've received two  communications -- from the bombers  to "Release Him."
We can't release him.
I know our stated policy is not to  negotiate with terrorists, but --
Hub, we can't release him because we  don't have him. We never had him.  And besides that, he's dead.
The CIA says --

The CIA? The CIA couldn't predict  the fall of the Berlin Wall until  bricks were hitting them in the head. (resuming) The Libyans snatched the Sheik --  some sectarian Muslim thing -- I'll  explain it next time you have a free  week. They killed him. Qaddafi put  out disinformation that it was us...  Who was your source on this?
Elise Kraft.
...A woman will never know the Middle  East. You're talking about a culture  that keeps its women slipcovered.  Elise Kraft can't tell a Sheik from  the prophylactic of the same name.
I appreciate the heads up.
Devereaux rises, offers his hand. As they shake, Elise st her head in the door without knocking.
Hub, we've got Judge Frankel in -- (as Devereaux turns  around) Oh. Hello, General.
Please, don't let me --
(to Hub) Sorry. That tip on the landlord looks  solid. The judge will see us right  away.
Sounds like I should get out of your  way. We're there if you need us. (at the door; to Elise) Your father well, Elise?
As can be expected. How's Maggie?
Top of her game. (heads out) Well, go get 'em.
And he's gone. Elise turns to Hub.
Making new friends.
How's your lip --?
She looks at Hub -- and now she knows that he knows. She  brazens it out:
So... you like to watch --?
No. Just learning about commitment.
It's a full contact sport.
Judge Frankel, 60, puts down his sandwich and wipes his h

-- You're telling me that just because  some Brooklyn landlord tips you off  that he's been paid in cash, you  have the right to call in the cavalry -- ! Hub, as far as I know, paying cash  is not yet a crime in this country.
You're not hearing me. This Khalil  was carrying cash for --
-- You've observed him giving cash  to --
... No, but --
-- But you have hard evidence linking  this apartment to the people that  blew up bus 87 --?
Elise sits quietly beside Frank, observing Hub's trials.
I know we'll turn up trace elements  of semtex, chemicals... something.
And when you do, you'll get your  warrant.
What about as a feasibility study?
Meaning?
We enter first, take a look, then  fill out the warrant.
Tell me the difference between that  and breaking-and-entering?
We're the good guys.
Not good enough.
What is good enough, Judge? Another  bus? A school, maybe. These things  come in waves.

Waves mean nothing to me; there's  been a wave of violent crime committed  by black people in this city for the  past twenty years, but if you came  to me with a plan to put all black  people behind bars as a preventative  measure I'd send you packing. There's  a price to be paid for living in a  free society --
-- and not in cash I guarantee it.
Hub catches Elise's eye -- "we're out of here."
Elise and Hub climb seemingly endless FLIGHTS OF STAIRS.
-- Not two Judges from now, not two  HOURS from now, not two MINUTES from  now. These guys could split any SECOND  and you've lost your best shot at --
Frank's working another warrant --
You don't understand, they're pros!  From the age of twelve they've been  dodging people like you, people better  than you.
You mean people like you?
-- no matter how sparkling your record  is, no matter how terrified you are  to fail --
Finally he stops, turns on her:
It's... against... the... law.
-- Just because you went to night  school, or filled out the back of a  matchbook or whatever you did to get  a law degree doesn't make you Sir  Thomas More.
Just because you talk the talk doesn't  make you an expert. And just because  you read my file doesn't make you an  expert on me.
You're gonna lose them and they're  gonna do another horrible --

-- You think I want to lose them.  Where do you get off talking that  shit. (controls himself...) If I don't take 'em down properly  they'll be on the street two hours  from now. I could find dynamite,  semtex, plutonium and a book of  matches in there and unless I've got  the right warrant it's all  inadmissible
They've also got a warrant. A warrant  from God. They're ready to die! And  your quaint laws don't mean shit to  these people.

My quaint laws? Last I checked you  were an American citizen. And these  happen to be the only laws we got. (turns on her) Look, I'm just a cop, okay, and I'm  real sorry the cold war's over, and  you Masters of the Universe got  nothing going on over there in  Afghanistan or Iraq or wherever --  but you're just not in the Middle  East anymore...
Oh, really...?
They reach the top of the stairs where Frank is waiting. dangles a piece of paper -- the warrant -- and grins.

head_text.subj: IN THE SAME SQUALID APARTMENT BUILDING

text: Hub looks through the surveillance equipment focused on a apartment across the street -- paper shades drawn. Wearin set of HEADPHONES, Elise listens intently to the Arabic  conversation.
They're discussing how hard it is to  find a decent cup of coffee over  here. (hands headset to  Frank) I make out three voices. What do you  have on the infrared?
Three sounds right. If we had  microwave we'd know for sure. The  CIA's got microwave, how come we  don't have microwave.
Hub, meanwhile is question a Syrian Landlord.
-- three of them. All day long they  watch tv. And eat pizza. Nothing but  pizza, pizza, pizza...
Hub looks over at Frank. They've got a way in.
Sequence omitted from original script. Sequence omitted from original script.
Mike Johannson, carrying two PIZZAS, knocks on a door.
Hub, Frank, and a small army of AGENTS lock and load.
Opens the door to the length of a chain and hands Mike a  twenty-dollar bill.
You want change, right --?
No.
You gonna open the door, or what --?
The Arab motions, leave them on the ground.
Jesus, didn't ya hear crime's down  seven-percent...
Muttering, he sets the pizza down and heads downstairs. A a moment we HEAR the chain pulled and the door open.
The Young Arab sets the pizza on an orange crate. Two oth YOUNG ARABS in the next room barely take their eyes off t rerun of "Hunter." But as the young Arab opens the box:
Hidden within, EXPLODES with a blinding FLASH, knocking h to the ground.
Is blown in as armed AGENTS rush in, Hub leading the way.
(English and Arabic) FBI --! Lie down on the floor with  your hands behind your back --!

head_text.subj: THE TWO OTHER YOUNG ARABS, HOWEVER --

text: Have not been affected. Not only were they in the next ro but also their eyes were averted from the FLASH.
But only get off half a clip each before they are CUT DOW by a fusillade of FBI return-fire.
The Young Arab, momentarily disoriented, stumbles to his  feet, only to be confronted by six armed agents -- all ai at his chest.
Drop your weapon!
The terrorist puts his gun to his mouth and PULLS THE TRI
As the CORDITE drifts lazily toward the ceiling, Hub call out from behind the table:
What about the others? See if we can  get a pulse --
Other Agents scurry in to hover over the inert BODIES.
Terminal.
Same here.
(softly) Gone.
Hub picks himself up in time to see Elise, kneeling besid the body of the Young Arab, her hand on his boyish chest.
We got semtex, we got detcord, same  stuff as the bus, the whole  enchilada...
A few WHOOPS and high-fives as the adrenaline rush of the firefight abates. Frank opens the remaining box.
Anybody like anchovies --?
Then from across the room, Hub kneels beside an ominous- looking DEVICE. A claymore mine.
Goddamn it. GODDAMN IT.
What --?
It didn't fire. They had it rigged  to the door and it didn't fire.
Frank stares at the lethal booby-trap. Hub shakes his hea
We're too old to be lucky, Frank.
Where Mike and Tina are dancing their asses off. Around t other AGENTS from the takedown laugh and drink.
Hub and Elise sit, watch them cut loose.
(sips her drink) My first boyfriend was Palestinian.  My father liked to say, they seduce  you with their suffering.
A WAITRESS brings her another drink.
You ever been over there --? (he shakes his head,  no) ...The courtesy with which they  welcome you into their homes. And  the people, these incredibly... warm  people in this... austere land.
But you work against them.
Only the crazies. I tend to be  suspicious of all true believers. (looks at him) Present company included.
So I'm a fanatic.
Let's just say you don't seem the  ambivalent type.
Is that right?
So why're are you a fed?
That's what my nephew keeps asking  me. "Why you with The Man, Unc?"
...Well? What'd you tell him?
You read my file. You tell me.
Let's see... Catholic school. Captain  of this, president of that. Hard  work, fair play, make a difference,  change the system from within. Rah.  Rah. Rah.
That was in my file?
...Tell me I'm wrong.
He studies her for a moment.
...What --?
You believe in anything, Elise --?
Like what, for instance?
How about right and wrong?
It's easy to choose between right  and wrong. What's hard is choosing  the wrong that's more right. I just  want to make it all... a little...  better. (finishes her drink) Ignore me. I'm shitfaced.
Frank appears to lean over their table.
So am I --! Hey, Elise... tell us  about being a spook? Ever meet Aldrich  Ames? Weren't you at the Bay of Pigs?
You were in charge of Waco, right -- ? Or was that Ruby Ridge?
The Shah of Iran, Noriega, I love  the way you guys predicted the  collapse of the Soviet Union.
Yeah, yeah, yeah... And J. Edgar  Hoover wore a dress.
She laughs and stands up to dance:
What do you say, Hub...? Peace?
But as he grudgingly stands up, a BALLAD comes on. They s there awkwardly. Finally, he takes her into his arms.
This feels like high school.
-- only my prom date wasn't packing  a gun.
Mine's a 9 mm. How big is yours?
Two inches. From the ground. (laughing, they dance  closer) So what's the latest from Samir. I  want a list of every visa he  sponsored.
Not sure he'll do it.
I once knew this undercover guy,  started to care so much about his  source --
-- Samir's a source. Period.
Have you considered that he might  also be in bed with the other side?
Samir in bed with them? That would  too much to wish for.
You're so confident.
Only in bed.
Tina watches them. She rolls her eyes at Frank. And then:
A low RUMBLE as the light FLICKERS and the chandelier swa
Whoa... What do they put in these  drinks --?
They got earthquakes in Manhattan?
But Elise is not too drunk to make her way to the door. H joins her. Already, in the distance, the WAILING OF SIREN
Blue light FLASHING. Hub, Elise and Frank sit grimly sile
Is snarled and gridlocked at 40th. Finally, they can take no longer and step out into a chorus of HONKING HORNS.
Past the frustrated drivers. Turning the corner at 41st w
From the New Victory Theatre -- where a gala benefit is t place.
Walks toward CAMERA. She's stunning. From the jeweled  clutchbag to the tasteful necklace, everything is perfect except:
And now we SEE:
Haphazardly pulled-up over the steps and the FIRETRUCKS  already unspooling their hoses. Cops, Firemen, EMT's.  Everybody's SCREAMING. Hub and Elise race past.
Sits, weeping quietly beneath the once proud stone lions.

Their faces cut and bleeding, stumble around, disoriented As Hub and Elise continue toward a SOUND we have never he before in this country. A kind of keening. A NYPD SERGEANT is the senior OFFICER on the scene. Hub s his shield to the man who appears a bit shell-shocked.
-- fucking bastards waited 'til  intermission. Everybody standing  around... Oh, Jesus...
GLASS crunching underfoot, they can only watch as horribl disfigured BODIES are carried out. A NEWS REPORTER shoves microphone in Hub's face.
Is it true the governor was attending  tonight's benefit --?
I don't know.
Who it is I'm speaking to --?
Hub ignores the reporter. He sees that Elise is already  tearing off part of her skirt to bandage a SOCIETY MATRON He takes off his coat and goes to work beside her.
Hub sits alone.
Folks, as you can probably tell, we  have begun our descent into  Washington's National airport.

head_text.subj: THE HIGH-PITCHED WHISTLING SOUND IS HEARD AGAIN

text: Hub reaches up to his DAMAGED EARS. As anyone who's ever  flown with a sinus problem knows, the pain is excruciatin
-- You alright?
But we can only LIP-READ her question. He's sweating now. Over this, we HEAR:
Either we answer this threat quickly  and convincingly or next week there'll  be a hundred more all over the world.
Sequence omitted from original script.
As Hub climbs the steps toward the gleaming dome, the deb continues within:
Sounds great, General, except why  can't we find out who's behind it -- ?
A strategy session chaired by General Devereaux. Sleeves  rolled up, silver coffee service. Staff members abound.
These sects are organized so you  need a kill to your credit to get  inside. It makes undercover operations  impossible. What that leaves us is...  we're working on it.
How about who's behind who's behind  this?
Libya. Iraq. Iran. Possibly Syria.
Ask a question. Get an atlas.
All I know is that we must respond.
Respond, sure. But how?
Find out who it is and bomb the shit  out of them.
And if we can't find out --?
The question hangs in the air.
Look it keeps escalating. First a  bus, then the theatre. What's next?
Anything but leadership.
With all respect, Senator, why don't  we just stipulate that the President  is a dumb son of a bitch so we can  all get down to business.
An icebreaker. Everyone laughs.
What about sending in the Guard?
The National Guard are trained for  riot control not counter-terrorism.
The Army then. I've seen the  contingency plans.
It's settled legal doctrine, posse  comitatus, that the Army not be turned  against our own people.
Even if that's what our own people  are asking for, three to one?
If the President is willing to declare  a State of Emergency --
President Lincoln declared martial  law in 1862. He suspended --
-- which the Supreme Court later  found un-constitutional. Ex parte  Milligan.
And I've got an election in November.  Ex-United States Congressman.
Guys, guys, the President lost a lot  of friends last night --
Not to mention six points in the  polls.
-- And his plane lands in two hours.  We owe it to him to have a consensus.
You don't fight a junkyard dog with  ASPCA rules. What you do is take the  leash off your own, bigger, meaner  dog.
...General?
The Army is a broadsword not a  scalpel. You do not want us in an  American city.
But hypothetically... how long would  it take you to --
We only go if the President invokes  the War Powers Act.
I understand that, General. Let us  imagine, though, for a moment, that  the order has been given.
CLOSE on Devereaux. As he weighs his remarks, we FLASHCUT almost imperceptibly to:
As WATER is poured over anonymous hands in a ritualized  manner. O.S. we HEAR the SOUND of chanting.

...Twelve hours after the President  gives the word we can be on the  ground. One light infantry division  of ten thousand seven hundred men.  Elements of the Rapid Deployment  Force combined with Special Forces --  Delta. APC's, tanks, helicopters.  And of course, the ubiquitous M-16A1  assault rifle, a humble weapon until  you see a man carrying one outside  your local bowling alley or Seven- Eleven. It will be noisy, it will be  scary and it will not be mistaken  for a VFW parade.
Where the same anonymous hands lift a cotton shroud. We w in SLOW-MOTION as it drifts down a shoulder.

That means civilian casualties. At a  minimum it's a drunk private joyriding  in a Hummer who runs down an old  lady in Greenpoint. At a maximum... (sighs) Make no mistake. We will hunt the  enemy. We will find the enemy. And  we will kill the enemy.
Turning the key in an ignition. An engine rumbles to life
(looks at them) And no card-carrying member of the  ACLU is more deadset against it...  than I am. Which is why I urge you...  no, I implore you not to consider  this option.
A long beat. The Chief of Staff sighs.
I know what the President will say.
What's that?
That's exactly why you're the only  man for the job.
Emerges from a dark garage like a beast from a cave.
The Army General speaks up.
I remind you General Devereaux does  not speak for official Army policy.  A police function has become accepted  as our role in Haiti, in Somalia --
-- Could I interrupt?
Everyone looks over at Hub. Devereaux smiles.
That's Anthony Hubbard, FBI. He's  the ASAC on the ground up there.  They took out the first cell less  than 36 hours after bus 87. I suggest  we hear what he has to say --
He nods to Hub, who acknowledges the vote of confidence.
There is something you probably  haven't thought about doing?
And that is --?

Nothing. Don't over-react. (off their incredulity) With all respect, gentlemen, I'm  just a cop. To you these people may  be martyrs, but to me they're  criminals. And a criminal is no more  than somebody who thinks he's better  than everyone else. And he's not  better. He only has to be wrong once.  And that's where we come in. We run  down a tip from a landlord, or we  pick up a latent print from a bus.  Our phones are ringing off the hook  with people from the Arab community  wanting to help.
He measures his words carefully. Unaccustomed to these ki of august circumstances.
They love this country and they hate  that these criminals are giving them  a bad name. With their help and some  old-fashioned shoe leather, we'll  nail these guys.
-- Amen to that.

Thank you, Agent Hubbard. I, too,  think we should proceed cautiously. (looks around) Now we've got an Agency briefing  prepared... Some of you may not know  Sharon Bridger. Sharon was posted in  Iraq as part of our covert operations  during the Gulf War. -- Sharon...
CLOSE ON -- HUB as, from behind him, comes a familiar VOI
We all know the traditional model of  a terrorist network. One cell  controlling all others. Cut off the  head and the body will wither.
Hub looks to the back of the room at Elise, who's no long Elise. She looks blithely at Hub as if nothing is amiss.
Unfortunately the old wisdom no longer  applies. The new paradigm is like  the myth of the Hydra. Each cell  exists independent of the other. Cut  off one head and another rises up in  its place.
Crossing the Brooklyn Bridge, keeping well below the spee limit. In the distance, the glass towers of Manhattan.
Bus 87 was the work of Cell #1. Its  elimination only activated the work  of Cell #2 -- the theatre gala.
Turns up Wall Street. Frank Haddad and Danny exit THE FED BUILDING. They pass Mike and Fred, heading back in. Somet about the van causes Frank to take notice.
And Cell #3? How do we find Cell #3?
Everyone looks to Sharon/Elise. Hub looks at her, too.
The question hangs in the air. She's thinking about somet What?
JUMPS THE CURB and heads across the plaza on A COLLISION  COURSE with the glass lobby of the FEDERAL BUILDING. Fran and Danny are rooted to the ground.
Close on Sharon/Elise. As time elongates. She knows.
We don't know.
Sequence omitted from original script.
Puffy clouds in a blue sky. As we TILT DOWN into:

Of what was once the Federal Building. RESCUE WORKERS hun for SURVIVORS as others carry BODY BAGS toward waiting  AMBULANCES. Hub stands sentinel to the grisly process as  indeed he has stood there all night. Frank is beside him.
-- Are they confirmed?
Fred, Whitney, we're waiting on who  else...
A JEEP pulls up and Elise/Sharon gets out.
Sharon.
Their silence speaks volumes. With Sharon is an OFFICER.
This is Colonel Hardwick. Army  Intelligence.
(shaking hands) Anthony Hubbard. Average intelligence. (clocking him) But 'til I hear otherwise this is  still my show.
I'm here as an advisor only. I intend  to keep a low profile.
I appreciate that, Colonel.
I don't mean to be insensitive, but  what, exactly, are your capabilities  at this point? Your... infrastructure --
You're standing on our infrastructure.  Excuse me.
Hub walks back toward the rubble. Sharon watches him go.
Sofas have been pushed against the wall. Hub's apartment serves as a temporary command post. Agents huddle togethe poring over the charred or soggy remnants of files.
-- They managed to get a partial  VIN# off the van. DMV says it was  reported stolen the day before in --
-- Brooklyn.
Fiber thinks they've come up with a  piece of the shroud. Egyptian cotton.
Frank joins them.
(grim) We just got a confirmation on Mike.  He was with Fred in the lobby.
How many does that make it --?
A KNOCK on the door. They look at one another. One of the agents answers it. Elise/Sharon. She walks over to them.
I'm... very sorry... about your  friends.
(giving her nothing) Frank. This is Sharon. (to her) -- I didn't catch the last name.
...Bridger. How ya doin' Frank?
Been better.
She nods. Takes from her purse a folder, labeled in Hebre
The agency has come up with another  list of probables.
She takes out photos. Neither Hub nor Frank react. She pu them on the coffee table. No one reaches for them.
I think we should circulate them. (they stonewall her:) Hey, this stuff may be good.
Why was there no warning from Samir?
Because he didn't know anything.
Says Samir.
Says me.
Maybe I'll ask him.
Over my dead body.
Over six hundred dead bodies.
They stare at one another. Both are tired and raw.
Look, he's one of the good guys.  Okay?
How the fuck can you be so sure?
Because he helped me recruit the  network in Iraq. OKAY?
He just stares at her.
We were part of the operation to  destabilize Saddam Hussein. Printing  up fake dinars, arming the Kurds --
-- and financing the Sheik.
He's Iraqi. He was going to be our  Ayatollah Khomeini --
-- And help bring down Saddam.
I ran the network. Samir was the go- between. He risked his life for us  over there.
So who are they? Give me names, Give  me pictures. Not some history lesson.
I can't give you pictures because I  don't know what they look like. We  did everything at arm's length.
So you got nothing.
I've got Samir.
Has he had any contact with them?
Minimal.
How does he do it?
He can't. They initiate.
And otherwise...
He's waiting.
He's waiting? What's he waiting for?  More bodies? We got lots more  buildings in midtown, maybe he's  waiting to see how many they can  blow up.
Look, I know how you must feel --
YOU DON'T KNOW SHIT HOW I FEEL -- MY  FRIENDS ARE DEAD. HUNDREDS OF PEOPLE  ARE DEAD.
They'll make contact soon.
How?... Why soon?
She looks at him, refusing to divulge anything more. Sudd Hub grabs her arm and roughly shoves her into:

(viciously) What's the tradecraft, Sharon?  Ironsites, visuals? I love all that  spy shit. (still, she says  nothing) I'm gonna haul your boy downtown,  strap his ass to a polygraph and ask  him all about you. Then I'm gonna  send the transcripts to a friend of  mine at the Times who just loves to  write about the latest CIA link to  some political horror show.
You burn him, you lose any chance  you ever had.
It's lose-lose from here on in, who  said that?
I'm not fucking with you.
How can you possibly remember who  you're fucking?
She slaps him, hard. Without hesitation he slaps her back She claws at his face, but he grabs her wrist and bends h arm behind her back.
I need... more time. Please. You're  hurting me. Please...
Something in the violence of the moment is more than a li charged.

head_text.subj: THE SURVEILLANCE OF SHARON AND SAMIR

text: A dead drop by a hot dog stand. Out for her morning jog. series of FREEZE FRAMES as the motordrive CLICKS AND WHIR
That's good sound.
Except they're not saying anything  worth listening to.
Sequence omitted from original script.
Samir chats with a couple of older men in the steaming wa
One's his uncle, he owns the place.  The other's a doctor. They check out  clean.
He go there every day?
A clean body and a pure heart.
Sequence omitted from original script. Sequence omitted from original script.
"Tonight we take a close look at the  tragic sight of a city under siege."
Hub sits on his sofa, watching the special report. Spread out before him, the surveillance PHOTOS of Sharon and Sam
A deserted Times Square. Police checking packages of shop in front of a department store. Long lines of security at bus stops.
Hub and Frank are walking downtown. At a stoptlight, A BU idles beside them, a POLICEMAN onboard.
-- claiming responsibility for the  bombing. In other news, a cab driver  was beaten and his cab set on fire.  The driver, Rashid Abu --
-- the Jews, man. When they say,  jump, we say, how high. I say we --
-- If you're on the State Department  Terrorist Watch list you cannot get  into this country. But Ali Waziri  was on the watch list, and he got  in.
Did you call the State Department?
They told me to call INS.
-- And?
They told me to call State.
Don't you just love government?
Is only the BUS backfiring. PEDESTRIANS who have thrown  themselves to the ground, screaming, now pick themselves Laughing. Only Hub and Frank are not laughing.
"As many fled, there were others who  stayed behind to pay the price...
Jammed freeways; A LOOTED corner deli, its Arab owners,  bloodied: POLICE checking backpacks at an elementary scho
Today, as hundreds of law enforcement  officials gathered in a Broadway  theatre, outside people wanted  answers.
Angry people, scared people. Hub, being interviewed about the coordinated efforts of law enforcement.
Already there is talk of a protest  march by a coalition of --

head_text.subj: INSIDE THE THEATRE, (A VIDEO CLIP TURNS BACK TO FILM)

text: Hub and a few others sit on the stage. Two hundred law  enforcement officials fill the orchestra seats.
THE PEOPLE OF THIS CITY HAVE A RIGHT --
-- THE PURPOSE OF THIS MEETING --!
-- IS TO MAKE THIS CITY SAFE...! And  your department --
My department WHAT, ASSHOLE...?
Sharon stands at the back, meets Hub's eye, and waves.
Guys... GUYS...
EVERYBODY'S talking at once. In frustration, Hub covers a microphone with his hand. The FEEDBACK silences the room.
Sorry. From now on, we will raise  our hands and wait to be called on --
An appreciative chuckle. Hub points to A MAN IN A SUIT.
Howard Kaplan. INS. So we've pulled  every ethnic visa in the city and  traced them to source. Who wants em?
Danny --?
We bring 'me in, have a talk.
What about translators --?
How many people we talking about  here?
Sixteen hundred, maybe more.
Where the hell we gonna put sixteen  hundred people?
Everyone again begins speaking at once. Hub takes control
What about a military presence at  JFK and LaGuardia --?
I don't think we're there yet. It's  also not going to stop these people.
What about protecting the Arab  population? There's a lot of anger --

I represent the American-Arab Anti- Discrimination Committee. Whatever  injustices my people may be suffering  at this difficult moment, we will  continue to show our patriotism and  our commitment to this country.
Thank you, sir. And to everyone else  for their patience today. These are  extremely difficult times -- London,  Paris, we're not the first city to  have to deal with this.
He pauses a moment, searching for the words.
In Tel Aviv, the day after they blew  up the market, the market was full. (looks out at them) This is New York. We can take it.
And then two hundred BEEPERS all go off at once. Everyone looks at one another. Dear God, what now...
Kids, huddled in a corner, crying. A dead mom. The legs o what we imagine is the terrorist. We are in:
Hub huddles with other agents behind a makeshift blast- barricade of desks and tables. Sharon kneels beside them.
-- one of the moms was carrying a  piece, wounds the guy as he's planting  the device. He kills her and locks  them all in. (points at video) Up there in the corner... by the  clock.
The probe is a hot-head, "arthroscopic" video camera.
-- It's got a timer on it only we  don't know how much time is left.
As Hub stares at the horrifying image, the WHITE-NOISE re and begins to GROW in his head.
Closer on the timer.
I'm trying but the angle's wrong...
The NOISE in Hub's head continues to grow. And then sudde it is compounded by the SOUND of an APPROACHING CHOPPER - as an NYPD SWAT HELICOPTER lowers itself into view.
What the fuck is the NYPD doing here?!
I don't know. Somebody must have --
-- WE'VE RUN DRILLS ON THIS  JURISDICTION BULLSHIT SINCE --
I KNOW --! YOU THINK I --
QUIT BICKERING AND FIX IT!
In the HELICOPTER -- a Marksman raises a sniper's rifle.
Is screaming now in Hub's head. Unimaginable. Unbearable.
(on his radio) NYPD SWAT, this is the FBI. Get that  bird the fuck out of there!
The SOUND of the CHOPPER and the WHITE NOISE drown him ou
Children are SCREAMING without sound. Even the chopper is drowned out by the WHITE NOISE.
The MARKSMAN takes careful aim --
The TERRORIST grabs a child as a human shield. Hub closes his eyes to the imminent nightmare, and then:
He takes off, barreling down the hall, toward the locked  door of the classroom.
He flies through it, firing, hitting the TERRORIST twice.

Much like the first one on Bus 99. Hub throws himself ove several SCREAMING CHILDREN. And for a moment we don't kno if they'll live or die, until: BLUE PAINT covers them all. Agents pour in, followed by  Sharon. There, on the floor, holding as many weeping chil as he can:

Who, unable to keep up the facade for a single second mor is also weeping now. Weeping for the victims of the bombi weeping for the children who've survived, weeping for him And for a moment, everyone just... stands there, vaguely  embarrassed, and more than a little moved.
Hub sits in his boxers, toweling blue paint from his hair listening to the CNN report of the school attack. A KNOCK the door. He pulls on his pants. It's Sharon.
This just came in.
She hands Hub another fax: "Last Warning. Release Him." H looks at it and hands it back to her without a word.
You alright?
My neck's a little stiff, that's  all.
(a long look) That's not what I meant.
I know.
They stand awkwardly in the doorway for a moment.
You want a drink?
Sure.
He walks over and opens a bottle of scotch.
That was a pretty crazy thing you  did today.
He doesn't respond. Hands her the drink.
Better days.
She takes a drink. Then another.
I wanted to -- I... just didn't feel  like... being alone... tonight.
Where's Samir?
I could call him. Maybe he'd join  us.
You'd like that.
I might. Or I could call Tina.
They stare at each other.
Look, I thought Samir'd be an easy  recruit. He wasn't. It was crazy but  I did what I had to do. (looks at him) You know as well as I do, running an  agent can be very... complicated.
How about running an FBI agent?
You think I'm trying to run you?
(looks at her) ...Why else are you here?
(staring right back) ...You know why I'm here.
It's a charged moment. They're two sad and lonely people.
Tell me to leave.
Leave.
No.
When they embrace, their ferocity and desperation is some more than comfort and less than love. Sequence omitted from original script.
The Chief of Staff is working late in a cardigan sweater. Devereaux, in his impeccable suit, stands opposite him. E at ease he is smartly erect.
The FBI received another fax.
Ahmed Bin Talal. They're still under  the impression that we have him.
Do we? Have him?
To refresh your memory, as I told  you last time, it was the Libyans  who --
I remember perfectly well what you  said last time. (looks at him) Do we?
Devereaux frosts him with a look.
Let me give you some free advice,  son. Don't get between me and the  President. You might break a nail.
I am speaking for the President.
He and Devereaux look at each other. It is the moment of  plausible deniability.
As far as the President is  concerned... No, we do not.
The Chief of Staff accepts the answer because it serves h for now. And because he has a more pressing agenda.

General, do you know that after  yesterday's attack, half the parents  in this country kept their children  out of school --? (Devereaux nods) ...They're attacking our way of life.  It's got to stop. And the President  cannot afford to be weak.
(reading the subtext) Are you saying the President is  prepared to take the necessary  steps...?
I'm saying, the President is prepared  to be... Presidential.
A ringing phone. Hub wakes up in a tangle of sheets. He l around and realizes he is alone. Did last night even happ
(on the phone) Hubbard... What --? ...Slow down,  slow down --
He reaches for the remote control, turns on the TV.

head_text.subj: A GRINDING OF TREADS ON ASPHALT

text: as THE FIRST APC enters Brooklyn. Followed by another. An another. And in a sound bite: General Devereaux, IN FATIG FOR THE FIRST TIME, and looking like grim death.
Today, with the invocation of the  War Powers Act by the President, I  am declaring a state of martial law  in this city.

head_text.subj: THE BATTLE OF BROOKLYN HAS BEGUN

text: Road blocks set up at select intersections. Random stop-a frisk. Patrols of young soldiers in the streets. GANG KID same age, same color, eye them warily.
To the best of our knowledge, we are  opposed by no more than twenty of  the enemy. He is hiding among a  population of roughly two million.
Is closed. SOLDIERS in full battle-dress stop cars, check trunks, handbags, briefcases, and id's. THE LINE OF HONKI ANGRY MOTORISTS stretches as far as the eye can see.
Intelligence tells us he is most  likely Arab-speaking, between the  age of fourteen and thirty. Narrowing  the target to fifteen thousand  suspects.
A SWARTHY TEENAGER is pulled from A CAR by a SERGEANT and led away to a CAMOUFLAGED TENT set up on the bridge.
We can further reduce that number  down to those who have been in this  country less than six months. Now  you have twenty hiding among two  thousand.
A CAR TRUNK is inspected. Two women waved through.

If you are one of these twenty young  men, you can hide among a population  of similar ethnic background.  Unfortunately for you, you can only  hide there. And that population, in  the classic immigration pattern, is  concentrated. Right here in Brooklyn.
Hub and Sharon stare at the Orwellian tableau.

We intend to seal off this borough.  And then we intend to squeeze it.  This is the land of opportunity,  gentlemen. The opportunity to turn  yourselves in. After sundown tonight  any young man fitting the profile I  described who has not cooperated  will be arrested and detained.
Hub and Sharon show their ID's to an MP.
Would you follow me, please. The  General is expecting you.
He leads him to A CAMOUFLAGED TENT on the service roadway
There is historically nothing more  corrosive to the morale of an army  than policing its own citizens.
